subsection.content: If an open-ended fund company refuses to register a transfer under subrule (1), the company must, within 2 months after the instrument of transfer is lodged, give the transferor and the transferee notice in writing of the refusal.

However, an open-ended fund company is not required to register a transfer or to give notice to any person if registering the transfer or giving the notice would result in a contravention of any applicable law.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (2), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Transfer by personal representative
section.content: A transfer of a share or other interest of a deceased shareholder of an open-ended fund company by the shareholder’s personal representative is as valid as if the personal representative had been the registered holder of the share or interest immediately before the transfer.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Transmission of shares by operation of law

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the right to shares in an open-ended fund company is transmitted to a person by operation of law; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person notifies the company in writing that the person wishes to be registered as a shareholder of the company in respect of the shares.

subsection.leadIn: The company must, within 2 months after receiving the notification, either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: register the person, in its register of shareholders, as a shareholder of the company in respect of the shares; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send the person notice of refusal of registration.

subsection.content: If an open-ended fund company refuses registration, the person may request a statement of the reasons for the refusal.

subsection.leadIn: If a person makes a request under subrule (3), the company must, within 28 days after receiving the request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: send the person the statement; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: register the person, in its register of shareholders, as a shareholder of the company in respect of the shares.

subsection.content: If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (2) or (4), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Compensation regarding forged share transfers

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: pay compensation to a person for loss arising from a transfer of shares in the company under a forged transfer or a transfer under a forged power of attorney;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide, by insurance, reservation of capital or accumulation of income, a fund to meet claims for compensation;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: borrow on the security of its property for the purpose of paying compensation; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: impose any reasonable restrictions on the transfer of its shares or with respect to powers of attorney for the transfer of its shares that the company considers necessary to guard against losses arising from forgery.

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company that pays compensation to a person under this rule has the same rights and remedies against the person liable for the loss as the person compensated would have had.

If the shares in an open-ended fund company have, by amalgamation or otherwise, become shares in another open-ended fund company, the other company has the same powers under this rule as the first company would have had if it had continued.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Treatment of redeemed shares
section.content: Shares of an open-ended fund company that have been redeemed or bought back by or otherwise transferred to the company are to be regarded as cancelled and the amount of the issued share capital of the company is reduced by the amount of consideration paid by the company for the shares.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Register of shareholders

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must keep in the English or Chinese language a register of shareholders.

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company must enter in the register of shareholders—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the names and addresses of its shareholders;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date on which each person is entered in the register as a shareholder; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date on which any person ceases to be a shareholder.

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company must enter in the register of shareholders, with the names and addresses of the shareholders, a statement of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the shares held by each shareholder, distinguishing each share by its number (if it has one), and the sub-fund (if any) and share class (if any) of such sub-fund to which the share belongs; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount paid or agreed to be considered as paid on the shares of each shareholder.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: An open-ended fund company that is a re-domiciled OFC must, within 2 months after the re-domiciliation date, enter in the register of shareholders, in respect of each shareholder as at that date, the particulars required under subrules (2) and (3). (33 of 2021 s. 20)

If an open-ended fund company issues a share to any person and the name of the person is not already entered in the register of shareholders, the company must, within 2 months after the date of issue of the share, enter in the register, in respect of the person, the particulars required under subrules (2) and (3).

An open-ended fund company must enter in the register of shareholders the particulars required under subrules (2) and (3) within 2 months after the company has received notice of the particulars concerned.

In the case of a person mentioned in subrule (2)(c), all entries in the register relating to the person on the date on which the person ceased to be a shareholder may be destroyed after the end of 10 years from that date.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1), (3A), (4) or (5), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues. (33 of 2021 s. 20)

section.name: s68
section.heading: Place where register must be kept

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company must keep its register of shareholders—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the company’s registered office; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at an alternative place in Hong Kong notified to the Registrar under subrule (2).

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must notify the Registrar of the place at which the register of shareholders is kept. The notice must be in the specified form and delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the register is first kept at that place.

Subrule (2) does not require an open-ended fund company to notify the Registrar of the place at which the register of shareholders is kept if the register has, at all times since it came into existence, been kept at the company’s registered office.

An open-ended fund company must notify the Registrar of any change (other than a change of the address of the company’s registered office) in the place at which the register of shareholders is kept. The notice must be in the specified form and delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the change.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1), (2) or (4), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Right to inspect and request copy

subsection.leadIn: A shareholder of an open-ended fund company is entitled, on request and without charge—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to inspect the entries in the register of shareholders of the company relating to the shareholder; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to be provided with a copy of the entries.

subsection.content: A person specified in subrule (3) (specified person) is entitled, on request and without charge, to inspect the register of shareholders of an open-ended fund company.

subsection.leadIn: Each of the following persons is a specified person for the purposes of subrule (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the custodian of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the investment manager of the company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Commission;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any public body or public officer that needs to inspect the register in order to properly perform the body’s or officer’s functions.

subsection.content: A specified person is entitled, on request and without charge, to be provided with a copy of the register, or any part of it.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Power to close register of shareholders
section.content: An open-ended fund company may, on giving notice in accordance with the provisions of its instrument of incorporation, close its register of shareholders, or the part of it relating to shareholders holding shares of any class, for any period or periods not exceeding in the whole 30 days in each year.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Power of Court to rectify register

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name of any person is, without sufficient cause, entered in or omitted from the register of shareholders of an open-ended fund company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: default is made or unnecessary delay takes place in entering in the register the fact of any person having ceased to be a shareholder,

subsection.continued: a person aggrieved, or any shareholder of the company, or the company, may apply to the Court for rectification of the register.

subsection.leadIn: If an application is made under subrule (1), the Court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuse the application; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: make any of the following orders—

subparagraph.content: an order to rectify the register;
an order on the company to pay damages for any loss sustained by any party aggrieved.

subsection.leadIn: On an application made under subrule (1), the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: may decide any question relating to the title of any person who is a party to the application to have the person’s name entered in or omitted from the register, whether the question arises—

subparagraph.content: between shareholders or alleged shareholders; or
between shareholders or alleged shareholders on the one hand and the open-ended fund company on the other hand; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: generally may decide any question necessary or expedient to be decided for rectification of the register.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Register to be proof in absence of contrary evidence
section.content: In the absence of evidence to the contrary, the register of shareholders of an open-ended fund company is proof of any matters that are by these Rules required or authorized to be entered in it.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Directors’ power to call general meeting
section.content: The directors of an open-ended fund company may call a general meeting of the company.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Shareholders’ power to request directors to call general meeting

subsection.content: The shareholders of an open-ended fund company may request the directors of the company to call a general meeting of the company.

The directors are required to call a general meeting if the company has received requests to do so from shareholders of the company representing at least 10% of the total voting rights of all the shareholders having a right to vote at general meetings.
The directors must call a meeting within 21 days after the date on which they become subject to the requirement under subrule (2).
A meeting called under subrule (3) must be held on a date not more than 28 days after the date of the notice convening the meeting.

If the requests received by the company identify a resolution that may properly be moved and is intended to be moved at the meeting, the notice of the meeting must include notice of the resolution and other contents as may be required under the company’s instrument of incorporation.
The business that may be dealt with at the meeting includes a resolution of which notice has been included in the notice of meeting in accordance with subrule (5).

If the resolution is to be proposed as a special resolution, the directors are to be regarded as not having duly called the meeting unless the notice of the meeting includes the text of the resolution and specifies the intention to propose the resolution as a special resolution.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Calling of extraordinary general meetings by shareholders

subsection.content: If the directors of an open-ended fund company are required under rule 74(2) to call a general meeting and do not do so in accordance with rule 74(3), the shareholders of the company who requested the meeting, or any of them representing more than one-half of the total voting rights of all of them, may themselves call a general meeting.
If the requests received by the company identify a resolution that may properly be moved and is intended to be moved at the meeting, the notice of the meeting must include notice of the resolution.
The meeting must be called for a date not more than 3 months after the date on which the directors become subject to the requirement to call a meeting.
The meeting must be called in the same manner, as nearly as possible, as that in which a meeting is required to be called by the directors.
The business that may be dealt with at the meeting includes a resolution of which notice has been included in the notice of meeting in accordance with subrule (2).
Any reasonable expenses incurred by the shareholders of the company requesting the meeting by reason of the failure of the directors duly to call a meeting must be reimbursed by the company.

Any sum so reimbursed must be retained by the company out of any sum due or to become due from the company by way of fees or other remuneration in respect of the services of the directors who were in default.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Shareholders’ power to call general meeting when there is no director, etc.

subsection.content: If at any time an open-ended fund company does not have any director, or does not have sufficient directors capable of acting to form a quorum, any director, or any 2 or more shareholders of the company representing at least 10% of the total voting rights of all the shareholders having a right to vote at general meetings, may call a general meeting in the same manner, as nearly as possible, as that in which general meetings may be called by the directors of the company.
Subrule (1) has effect in so far as the company’s instrument of incorporation does not make other provision in that behalf.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Power of Court to order meeting

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if, for any reason, it is impracticable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to call a general meeting of an open-ended fund company in any manner in which general meetings of the company may be called; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to conduct the meeting in the manner prescribed by the company’s instrument of incorporation or these Rules.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may, either of its own motion or on application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a director of the open-ended fund company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by a shareholder of the open-ended fund company who would be entitled to vote at the meeting,

subsection.continued: order a general meeting of the company to be called, held and conducted in the manner the Court thinks fit.

subsection.content: If the order is made, the Court may give ancillary or consequential directions that the Court thinks expedient.
Directions given under subrule (3) may include a direction that 1 shareholder of the company present at the meeting in person or by proxy is to be regarded as constituting a quorum.
A general meeting called, held and conducted in accordance with an order under subrule (2) is to be regarded for all purposes as a general meeting of the company duly called, held and conducted.

The legal personal representative of a deceased shareholder of the company is to be regarded in all respects, for the purposes of this rule, as a shareholder of the company having the same rights with respect to attending and voting at a meeting of the company as the deceased shareholder would, if living, have had.

section.name: s78
section.heading: Notice of general meetings

subsection.content: A general meeting of an open-ended fund company must be called in accordance with the company’s instrument of incorporation.

subsection.leadIn: A general meeting (other than an adjourned meeting) of an open-ended fund company must be called by notice of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at least 14 days; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a longer period specified in the company’s instrument of incorporation.

subsection.leadIn: Notice of a general meeting of an open-ended fund company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must contain the particulars set out in the company’s instrument of incorporation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be given in the manner set out in that instrument.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Persons entitled to receive notice of general meeting

subsection.leadIn: Notice of a general meeting of an open-ended fund company must be given to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every shareholder of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every director of the company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the investment manager of the company; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the custodian of the company.

subsection.content: In subrule (1), the reference to a shareholder includes any person who is entitled to a share in consequence of the death or bankruptcy of a shareholder, if the company has been notified of that person’s entitlement.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Duty to give notice of general meeting to auditor

subsection.content: If notice of a general meeting of an open-ended fund company or any other document relating to the general meeting is required to be given to a shareholder of the company, the company must give a copy of it to its auditor at the same time as the notice or the other document is given to the shareholder.
If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Contents of notice of general meeting

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company must ensure that a notice of a general meeting of the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specifies the date and time of the meeting;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specifies the place of the meeting (and if the meeting is to be held in 2 or more places, the principal place of the meeting and the other place or places of the meeting);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: states the general nature of the business to be dealt with at the meeting; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if a resolution is intended to be moved at the meeting—

subparagraph.content: includes notice of the resolution; and
includes or is accompanied by a statement containing the information and explanation (if any) that is reasonably necessary to indicate the purpose of the resolution.

subsection.content: Subrule (1)(a), (b) and (c) has effect subject to the company’s instrument of incorporation.
Subrule (1)(d) does not apply in relation to a resolution of which notice has been included in the notice of meeting under rule 74(5) or 75(2).
The validity of a resolution, if passed at a general meeting of an open-ended fund company, is not affected by a contravention of subrule (1)(d).
Subrule (4) does not affect any common law rules or equitable principles, or the provisions of any other Ordinance, as regards the validity of a resolution.

section.name: s82
section.heading: Resolution requiring special notice

subsection.content: If, by these Rules, special notice is required to be given of a resolution, the resolution is not effective unless notice of the intention to move it has been given to the open-ended fund company at least 28 days before the meeting at which it is moved.
The company must, if practicable, give its shareholders notice of the resolution at the same time and in the same manner as it gives notice of the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: If that is impracticable, the company must give its shareholders notice of the resolution at least 14 days before the meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by advertisement in a newspaper circulating generally in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other manner allowed by the company’s instrument of incorporation.

subsection.content: If, after notice of the intention to move the resolution has been given to the company, a meeting is called for a date 28 days or less after the notice has been given, the notice is to be regarded as having been properly given, though not given within the time required.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Accidental omission to give notice of meeting or resolution

subsection.leadIn: If an open-ended fund company gives notice of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a general meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a resolution intended to be moved at a general meeting,

subsection.continued: any accidental omission to give notice to, or any non-receipt of notice by, any person entitled to receive notice must be disregarded for the purpose of determining whether notice of the meeting or resolution is duly given.

subsection.content: Except in relation to notice given under rule 74 or 75, subrule (1) has effect subject to the company’s instrument of incorporation.

section.name: s84
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: circulation date (傳閱日期), in relation to a written resolution or a proposed written resolution, means the date on which copies of the resolution are sent to the shareholders under rule 90(6) or if copies are sent to shareholders on different days, the first of those days.

section.name: s85
section.heading: Representation of body corporate at meetings

subsection.leadIn: A body corporate may, by resolution of its directors or other governing body—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if it is a shareholder of an open-ended fund company, authorize any person it thinks fit to act as its representative at any meeting of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it is a creditor of an open-ended fund company, authorize any person it thinks fit to act as its representative at a meeting of creditors of the company.

subsection.content: A person authorized under subrule (1) is entitled to exercise the same powers on behalf of the body corporate as that body corporate could exercise if it were an individual shareholder or creditor of the company.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Representation of recognized clearing house at meetings

subsection.content: A recognized clearing house may, if it or its nominee is a shareholder of an open-ended fund company, authorize any person it thinks fit to act as its representative at any meeting of the company.
If more than one person is authorized under subrule (1), the authorization must specify the number and class of shares in respect of which each person is so authorized.

A person authorized under subrule (1) is entitled to exercise the same powers on behalf of the recognized clearing house (or its nominee) as that clearing house (or its nominee) could exercise if it were an individual shareholder of the company.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Resolutions at meetings

subsection.leadIn: A resolution of an open-ended fund company is validly passed at a general meeting if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notice of the meeting and of the resolution is given;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the meeting is held and conducted; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the resolution is passed,

subsection.continued: in accordance with this Part and the company’s instrument of incorporation.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subrule (1), if there is any inconsistency between a provision of this Part and a provision of the open-ended fund company’s instrument of incorporation, unless otherwise provided in the provision of this Part, the provision of this Part prevails over the provision of the instrument of incorporation to the extent of the inconsistency.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Ordinary resolution

subsection.content: An ordinary resolution of the shareholders (or of a class of shareholders) of an open-ended fund company means a resolution that is passed by a simple majority.

subsection.leadIn: A resolution passed at a general meeting on a show of hands is passed by a simple majority if it is passed by a simple majority of the total of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of the shareholders who (being entitled to do so) vote in person on the resolution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of the persons who vote on the resolution as duly appointed proxies of shareholders entitled to vote on it.

subsection.content: A resolution passed on a poll taken at a general meeting is passed by a simple majority if it is passed by shareholders representing a simple majority of the total voting rights of all the shareholders who (being entitled to do so) vote in person or by proxy on the resolution.
Anything that may be done by an ordinary resolution may also be done by a special resolution.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Special resolution

subsection.content: A special resolution of the shareholders (or of a class of shareholders) of an open-ended fund company means a resolution that is passed by a majority of at least 75%.

subsection.leadIn: A resolution passed at a general meeting on a show of hands is passed by a majority of at least 75% if it is passed by at least 75% of the total of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of the shareholders who (being entitled to do so) vote in person on the resolution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of the persons who vote on the resolution as duly appointed proxies of shareholders entitled to vote on it.

subsection.content: A resolution passed on a poll taken at a general meeting is passed by a majority of at least 75% if it is passed by shareholders representing at least 75% of the total voting rights of all the shareholders who (being entitled to do so) vote in person or by proxy on the resolution.

subsection.leadIn: If a resolution is passed at a general meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the resolution is not a special resolution unless the notice of the meeting included the text of the resolution and specified the intention to propose the resolution as a special resolution; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the notice of the meeting so specified, the resolution may only be passed as a special resolution.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Written resolutions

subsection.content: Anything that may be done by a resolution passed at a general meeting of an open-ended fund company may be done, without a meeting and without any previous notice being required, by a written resolution of the shareholders of the company.

Anything that may be done by a resolution passed at a meeting of a class of shareholders of an open-ended fund company may be done, without a meeting and without any previous notice being required, by a written resolution of that class of shareholders of the company.

subsection.leadIn: A resolution may be proposed as a written resolution by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the directors of an open-ended fund company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shareholders of the company representing not less than the requisite percentage of the total voting rights of all the shareholders entitled to vote on the resolution.

subsection.content: The requisite percentage mentioned in subrule (3)(b) is 5% or a lower percentage specified for this purpose in the open-ended fund company’s instrument of incorporation.

If a resolution is required by these Rules to be passed as an ordinary resolution or a special resolution, the resolution may be passed as a written resolution; and a reference in these Rules to an ordinary resolution or a special resolution includes a written resolution.

If a resolution is proposed as a written resolution under subrule (3), the company must send a copy of the resolution to every shareholder of the company in hard copy form or in electronic form or, send such a copy to all shareholders by making the copy available on a website.
A reference in any Ordinance to the date of passing of a resolution or the date of a meeting is, in relation to a written resolution, the date on which the written resolution is passed under rule 92.

subsection.leadIn: A written resolution of an open-ended fund company has effect as if passed by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company at a general meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a meeting of the relevant class of shareholders of the company,

subsection.continued: and a reference in these Rules to a meeting at which a resolution is passed or to shareholders voting in favour of a resolution is to be construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: This rule does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a resolution removing an auditor before the end of the auditor’s term of office; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a resolution removing a director before the end of the director’s term of office.

section.name: s91
section.heading: Company’s duty to notify auditor, custodian and investment manager of proposed written resolution

subsection.leadIn: If an open-ended fund company is required to send a copy of a resolution to a shareholder of the company under rule 90(6), it must, on or before the circulation date, send to the auditor, the custodian and the investment manager of the company a copy of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the resolution; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other document relating to the resolution that is to be sent to a shareholder together with that resolution.

subsection.content: The validity of the resolution, if passed, is not affected by a contravention of subrule (1).

section.name: s92
section.heading: Procedure for signifying agreement to proposed written resolution

subsection.content: A written resolution is passed when all eligible shareholders of an open-ended fund company have signified their agreement to it.

subsection.leadIn: A shareholder signifies agreement to a proposed written resolution when the open-ended fund company receives from the shareholder (or from someone acting on the shareholder’s behalf) a document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identifying the resolution to which it relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: indicating the shareholder’s agreement to the resolution.

subsection.content: A shareholder’s agreement to a written resolution, once signified, may not be revoked.

For the purposes of this rule, the eligible shareholders of an open-ended fund company are the shareholders of the company who would have been entitled to vote on the proposed written resolution on the circulation date of the resolution.

section.name: s93
section.heading: Period for agreeing to proposed written resolution

subsection.leadIn: A proposed written resolution lapses if it is not passed before the end of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period specified for this purpose in the open-ended fund company’s instrument of incorporation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if none is specified, the period of 28 days beginning on the circulation date.

subsection.content: The agreement of a shareholder to a proposed written resolution is ineffective if signified after the end of that period.

section.name: s94
section.heading: Company’s duty to notify shareholders, auditor, investment manager and custodian that written resolution has been passed
section.leadIn: If a resolution of an open-ended fund company is passed as a written resolution, the company must, within 15 days after the resolution is passed, send a notice of this fact to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every shareholder of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the auditor of the company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the investment manager of the company; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the custodian of the company.

section.name: s95
section.heading: Relationship between rules 90, 91, 92, 93 and 94 and provisions of company’s instrument of incorporation

subsection.content: A provision of an open-ended fund company’s instrument of incorporation is void in so far as it would have the effect that a resolution that is required by or otherwise provided for in an Ordinance could not be proposed and passed as a written resolution.

Nothing in rules 90, 91, 92, 93 and 94 affects any provision of an open-ended fund company’s instrument of incorporation authorizing the company to pass a resolution without a meeting, otherwise than in accordance with those rules.
Subrule (2) applies only if the resolution has been agreed to by all the shareholders of the open-ended fund company who are entitled to vote on the resolution.

section.name: s96
section.heading: Records of resolutions and meetings

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company must keep records comprising—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: copies of all resolutions of shareholders passed otherwise than at general meetings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: minutes of all proceedings of general meetings.

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must keep the copies of resolutions or minutes of proceedings under subrule (1) for at least 10 years from the date of the resolution or meeting.
A record of a resolution kept under subrule (1) is evidence of the passing of the resolution.
The minutes of proceedings of a general meeting of an open-ended fund company are evidence of the relevant proceedings.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1) or (2), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $1,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s97
section.heading: Registration of and requirements relating to certain resolutions, etc.

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a resolution of an open-ended fund company for the purpose of or in relation to the winding up of the company under Part 11;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a resolution varying any matter in, or provision of, the instrument of incorporation of an open-ended fund company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an order of the Court that alters the instrument of incorporation of an open-ended fund company; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an order of the Court that alters a resolution referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

subsection.content: The open-ended fund company must deliver a copy of the resolution or order under subrule (1) to the Registrar for registration within 14 days after it is passed or made.

subsection.leadIn: The company must ensure that a copy of the resolution or order of the Court that is for the time being in force is included in or annexed to every copy of its instrument of incorporation issued—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after the passing of the resolution; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after the making of the order of the Court.

subsection.content: If the resolution is not in writing, a reference to a copy of the resolution in subrules (2) and (3) is to be construed as a written memorandum setting out the terms of the resolution.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (2), the company, and a liquidator of the company who authorizes or permits, or participates in the contravention, commit an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (3), the company, and a liquidator of the company who authorizes or permits, or participates in the contravention, commit an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s98
section.heading: Place where records must be kept

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must keep its records of resolutions and meetings at the company’s registered office or an alternative place in Hong Kong notified to the Registrar.

An open-ended fund company must notify the Registrar of the place at which the records mentioned in subrule (1) are kept. The notice must be in the specified form and delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the records are first kept at that place.

An open-ended fund company must notify the Registrar of any change (other than a change of the address of the company’s registered office) in the place at which the records mentioned in subrule (1) are kept. The notice must be in the specified form and delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the change.

Subrule (2) does not require an open-ended fund company to notify the Registrar of the place at which the records mentioned in subrule (1) are kept if they have at all times been kept at the company’s registered office.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1), (2) or (3), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $1,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s99
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: non-Hong Kong custodian (非香港保管人)—(a)means a custodian incorporated outside Hong Kong; but(b)does not include a custodian that is a re-domiciled company; (14 of 2025 s. 260)

required details (所需細節), in relation to a process agent, means the name of the process agent and—(a)if the process agent is an individual, the process agent’s usual residential address in Hong Kong;(b)if the process agent is a company, the address of the company’s registered office in Hong Kong; or(c)if the process agent is a partnership, the principal place of business of the partnership in Hong Kong.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Eligibility for appointment
section.content: The experience and expertise of the persons appointed as directors of an open-ended fund company, taken together, must be appropriate for carrying on the business of the company.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Appointment of directors

subsection.leadIn: Any appointment of a director (other than a first director) of an open-ended fund company must be made— (33 of 2021 s. 21)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the company is required to hold an annual general meeting under its instrument of incorporation—by the company by way of ordinary resolution passed at a general meeting, except that the directors may appoint a person to act as a director to fill any vacancy until the next annual general meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if there is no requirement for an annual general meeting under the company’s instrument of incorporation—by the directors of the company.

statutoryNote.heading: Note—
statutoryNote.content: As to the first directors of an open-ended fund company—see section 112U(2) of the Ordinance. (33 of 2021 s. 21)

subsection.content: An appointment under this rule or rule 103 must not be made unless the Commission has given its approval to the appointment.
An appointment of a director in contravention of subrule (3) or rule 100 is of no effect.

section.name: s102
section.heading: Non-resident director to have process agent

subsection.content: A non-resident director of an open-ended fund company must have a process agent.

subsection.leadIn: Any process or notice required to be served on a non-resident director is sufficiently served if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is addressed to the director’s process agent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is left at, or sent by post to, the process agent’s address contained in the record kept by the company under subrule (3).

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must keep a record of every person who is a process agent of a non-resident director (record) at the place at which the register of directors of the company is kept under rule 104(2).
The record must, in respect of each process agent of a non-resident director, contain the required details.

Any person is entitled, on request made in the manner specified by the open-ended fund company and without charge, to inspect the record, and on payment of such reasonable fee as the company determines, to be provided with a copy of the record, or any part of it.

If there is a change in the particulars in the record, the company must, within 15 days after the change, deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice in the specified form containing the particulars of the change and the date on which it occurred.

A non-resident director of an open-ended fund company must give notice to the company of any matters relating to a process agent of the director that are required for the purposes of subrules (3), (4) and (6).

If a person contravenes subrule (1), (3), (6) or (7), the person commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Removal of directors

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company may, by ordinary resolution passed at a general meeting, remove a director before the end of the director’s term of office, despite anything in the company’s instrument of incorporation or in any agreement between the company and the director.
Subrules (3), (4), (5) and (6) apply in relation to the removal of a director of an open-ended fund company by resolution.

subsection.leadIn: Special notice is required of a resolution—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to remove a director of an open-ended fund company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to appoint a person in place of a director so removed at the meeting at which the director is removed.

subsection.content: A vacancy created by the removal of a director of an open-ended fund company, if not filled at the meeting at which the director is removed, may be filled as a casual vacancy.

A person appointed in place of a removed director is to be regarded, for the purpose of determining the time at which the person or any other director is to retire, as if the person had become a director on the day on which the person removed was last appointed a director.

In relation to a resolution to remove a director of an open-ended fund company before the end of the director’s term of office, no share may, on a poll, carry a greater number of votes than it would carry in relation to the generality of matters to be voted on at a general meeting of the company.

subsection.leadIn: This rule is not to be regarded as depriving a person of compensation or damages payable to the person in respect of the termination of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s appointment as director; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any appointment terminating with that as director.

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must, within 14 days after passing a resolution to remove a director, give notice in writing to the Commission of the resolution.

section.name: s104
section.heading: Register of directors

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must keep in the English or Chinese language a register of directors.

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company must keep the register of directors—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the company’s registered office; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at an alternative place in Hong Kong notified to the Registrar under subrule (3).

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must notify the Registrar of the place at which the register of directors is kept. The notice must be in the specified form and delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the register is first kept at that place.

An open-ended fund company must notify the Registrar of any change (other than a change of the address of the company’s registered office) in the place at which the register of directors is kept. The notice must be in the specified form and delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the change.

Subrule (3) does not require an open-ended fund company to notify the Registrar of the place at which the register of directors is kept if the register has at all times been kept at the company’s registered office.

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company must enter in the register of directors the following particulars of each person who is a director of the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the present forename and surname, former forename or surname (if any), and aliases (if any);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the usual residential address; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number of the identity card or, if the director does not have an identity card, the number and issuing country of any passport held by the director.

subsection.content: If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1), (2), (3), (4) or (6), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: In subrule (6)—
subsection.def: forename (名字) includes a Christian or given name;

residential address (住址)—(a)does not include an address at a hotel unless the person to whom it relates is stated, for the purposes of this rule, to have no other permanent address; and(b)does not include a post office box number;
surname (姓氏), for a person usually known by a title different from the person’s surname, means that title.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule, a reference to a former forename or surname does not include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to a person—

subparagraph.content: a forename or surname that was changed or ceased to be used before the person attained the age of 18 years; and
a forename or surname that has been changed or ceased to be used for a period of at least 20 years;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a person usually known by a title different from the person’s surname, the name by which the person was known before the adoption of or succession to the title; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in relation to a married woman, a name or surname by which she was known before her marriage.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Right to inspect and request copy

subsection.content: A shareholder of an open-ended fund company is entitled, on request made in the manner specified in the company’s instrument of incorporation and without charge, to inspect the register of directors of the company.
Any other person is entitled, on request and on payment of such reasonable fee as the open-ended fund company determines, to inspect the register.
A person is entitled, on request and on payment of such reasonable fee as the company determines, to be provided with a copy of the register, or any part of it.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Duty to notify Registrar of appointment of director etc.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is appointed as a director of an open-ended fund company otherwise than under section 112U(2) of the Ordinance, the company must, within 15 days after the appointment, deliver to the Registrar for registration, in the manner specified in subrule (2), a notice in the specified form containing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the director’s particulars specified in its register of directors;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a statement that the person has accepted the appointment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a statement that the person has attained the age of 18 years; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the person is a non-resident director, the required details of the director’s process agent.

subsection.content: The manner of delivery referred to in subrule (1) is delivery to the Commission.
The Commission must, as soon as reasonably practicable after receiving the notice specified in subrule (1), send the notice to the Registrar.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Duty to notify Registrar of cessation of appointment etc.

subsection.leadIn: If a person ceases to be a director of an open-ended fund company or there is any change in the particulars contained in the register of directors of the company, the company must, within 15 days after the cessation or change, deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice in the specified form containing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the particulars of cessation or change and the date on which it occurred; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other matters that are specified in the form.

subsection.content: If a director of the open-ended fund company resigns as director and has reasonable grounds for believing that the company will not deliver the notice under subrule (1), the director resigning must deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice of the resignation in the specified form.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s108
section.heading: Duty of director to make disclosure

subsection.content: A director of an open-ended fund company must give notice to the company of matters relating to the director that are required for the purposes of rules 104(6), 106 and 107.
A director who contravenes subrule (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Registrar to keep index of directors

subsection.content: The Registrar must keep an index of every person who is a director of an open-ended fund company.

subsection.leadIn: The particulars contained in the index must, in respect of each director, include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name and address of the director, and the number of the identity card or, if the director does not have an identity card, the number and issuing country of any passport held by the director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the latest particulars sent under rules 106(1)(a) and 107(1) to the Registrar in respect of the director; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the name of each open-ended fund company of which the director can be identified as a director.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Director must declare material interests

subsection.content: If a director of an open-ended fund company is in any way, directly or indirectly, interested in a transaction, arrangement or contract, or a proposed transaction, arrangement or contract, with the company that is significant in relation to the company’s business, and the director’s interest is material, the director must declare the nature and extent of the director’s interest to the other directors in accordance with rule 111 and the provisions of the company’s instrument of incorporation.

subsection.leadIn: This rule does not require a director of an open-ended fund company to declare an interest—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the director is not aware of the interest or the transaction, arrangement or contract in question; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if, or to the extent that, the interest concerns the terms of the director’s service contract that have been or are to be considered by—

subparagraph.content: a meeting of the directors; or
a committee of the directors appointed for the purpose under the company’s instrument of incorporation.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subrule (2)(a), a director is to be regarded as being aware of matters of which the director ought reasonably to be aware.

This rule does not affect the operation of any other Ordinance or rule of law restricting a director of an open-ended fund company from having any interest in a transaction, arrangement or contract with the company.
A director who contravenes subrule (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6.

section.name: s111
section.heading: Declaration to directors

subsection.content: A declaration of interest under rule 110 in a transaction, arrangement or contract that has been entered into must be made as soon as reasonably practicable.
A declaration of interest under rule 110 in a proposed transaction, arrangement or contract must be made before the open-ended fund company enters into the transaction, arrangement or contract.

subsection.leadIn: A declaration of interest under rule 110 must be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at a directors’ meeting;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by notice in writing sent by the director to the other directors; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by notice in writing sent to the open-ended fund company.

subsection.leadIn: If a declaration of interest to directors under rule 110 is made by notice in writing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the making of the declaration is to be regarded as forming part of the proceedings at the next directors’ meeting after the notice is given; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: rule 112 applies as if the declaration had been made at the meeting.

section.name: s112
section.heading: Minutes of directors’ meetings

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company must cause the following to be recorded—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: minutes of all proceedings at meetings of its directors; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all resolutions passed by its directors without a meeting.

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company must keep the records under subrule (1) for at least 10 years from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date of the passing of the resolution without a meeting.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Minutes as evidence

subsection.content: Minutes recorded in accordance with rule 112, if purporting to be signed by the chairperson of the meeting or by the chairperson of the next directors’ meeting, are evidence of the proceedings at the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: If the proceedings at a meeting of directors are evidenced by minutes under subrule (1), then, unless there is evidence to the contrary—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the meeting is to be regarded as having been duly held and convened;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all proceedings at the meeting are to be regarded as having duly taken place; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: all appointments at the meeting are to be regarded as valid.

subsection.content: Subrule (2)(c) is subject to sections 112V(2) and 112W(2) of the Ordinance.

section.name: s114
section.heading: Appointment of custodian

subsection.content: With effect from the date of incorporation of an open-ended fund company, the person named in the application made under section 112D or 112ZJB of the Ordinance in respect of the company as custodian is deemed to be appointed as the company’s custodian for the purposes of section 112ZA(1) of the Ordinance. (33 of 2021 s. 22)
Any subsequent appointment of a custodian of an open-ended fund company must be made by the directors of the company.
An appointment under subrule (2) must not be made unless the Commission has given its approval to the appointment.
An appointment made in contravention of subrule (3) is of no effect.

subsection.leadIn: A person who makes an appointment in contravention of subrule (3) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s115
section.heading: Non-Hong Kong custodian to have process agent

subsection.content: A non-Hong Kong custodian of an open-ended fund company must have a process agent.

subsection.leadIn: Any process or notice required to be served on a non-Hong Kong custodian is sufficiently served if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is addressed to the custodian’s process agent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is left at, or sent by post to, the process agent’s address contained in the record kept by the open-ended fund company under subrule (3).

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must keep a record of every person who is a process agent of a non-Hong Kong custodian (record) at the place at which the register of directors of the company is kept under rule 104(2).
The record must, in respect of a process agent of a non-Hong Kong custodian, contain the required details.

Any person is entitled, on request made in the manner specified by the open-ended fund company and without charge, to inspect the record and, on payment of such reasonable fee as the company determines, to be provided with a copy of the record, or any part of it.
A custodian of an open-ended fund company must give notice to the company of any matters relating to a process agent of the custodian that are required for the purposes of subrules (3) and (4).
This rule does not apply to a non-Hong Kong custodian that is a registered non-Hong Kong company.

If a person contravenes subrule (1), (3) or (6), the person commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

statutoryNote.heading: Note—
statutoryNote.content: For the service of process or notice on a non-Hong Kong custodian that is a registered non-Hong Kong company—see section 803 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622).

section.name: s116
section.heading: Rights of custodian
section.leadIn: A custodian of an open-ended fund company is entitled—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be given all notices of, and other communications relating to, any general meeting of the company as a shareholder of the company is entitled to be given;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to attend any general meeting of the company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to be heard at any general meeting of the company that the custodian attends on any part of the business of the meeting that concerns the custodian as custodian of the company;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to request in writing the directors to convene a general meeting of the company when the custodian sees fit;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to require from the company’s officers information and explanations that the custodian thinks necessary for the performance of the custodian’s functions; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to have access, except in so far as they concern the appointment or removal of the custodian, to any reports, statements or other papers that are to be considered at any meeting held by the directors of the company (when acting in their capacity as such), at any general meeting of the company or at any meeting of holders of shares of any particular class.

section.name: s117
section.heading: Sub-custodians
section.content: A sub-custodian of an open-ended fund company must take reasonable care, skill and diligence to ensure the safe keeping of the scheme property of the company that is entrusted to the sub-custodian.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Resignation etc. of custodian

subsection.content: A person may resign as custodian of an open-ended fund company by giving the company a notice in writing that is accompanied by a statement required to be given under rule 119(1).

If a person ceases to be a custodian of an open-ended fund company, other than by virtue of an order of the Court made under section 213 of the Ordinance, the company must, within 15 days after the cessation, give notice in writing of the cessation to the Commission.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (2), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s119
section.heading: Statement by custodian ceasing to hold office

subsection.leadIn: If a person ceases to hold office as custodian of an open-ended fund company other than by virtue of an order of the Court made under section 213 of the Ordinance, the person must give the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person considers that there are circumstances connected with the person’s ceasing to hold office that should be brought to the attention of the company’s shareholders or creditors, a statement of those circumstances; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person considers that there are no such circumstances, a statement to that effect.

subsection.content: The person must send a copy of the statement under subrule (1) to the Commission at the same time the person gives the statement to the company under the subrule.

Despite that the person giving the statement has ceased to hold office as custodian, the person has the rights conferred by rule 116(a), (b) and (c) in relation to the general meeting of the company following the date on which the statement was given under subrule (1).

The reference in rule 116(c) to business of the meeting that concerns the custodian as custodian of the company is, in relation to a custodian who has ceased to hold office, a reference to business of the meeting that concerns the custodian as former custodian of the company.

section.name: s120
section.heading: Open-ended fund company’s and aggrieved person’s responses to statement of circumstances

subsection.leadIn: If an open-ended fund company is given a statement of circumstances under rule 119(1)(a), the company must, within 14 days beginning on the date on which the company receives the statement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: send a copy of the statement to every shareholder of the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply to the Court for an order directing that copies of the statement are not to be sent under paragraph (a).

subsection.content: If an open-ended fund company makes an application under subrule (1)(b), it must give notice of the application to the person who has given the statement of circumstances to the company.

A person who claims to be aggrieved by a statement of circumstances may, within 14 days beginning on the date on which the company receives the statement, apply to the Court for an order directing that copies of the statement are not to be sent under subrule (1)(a).

subsection.leadIn: If a person makes an application under subrule (3), the person must give notice of the application to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person who has given the statement of circumstances to the company.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person gives an open-ended fund company a statement of circumstances; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within 21 days beginning on the date on which the company receives the statement, the person has not received notice of an application under subrule (2) or (4),

subsection.continued: the person must, within the next 7 days, deliver to the Registrar for registration, a copy of the statement.

section.name: s121
section.heading: Offences relating to rule 120

subsection.leadIn: If an open-ended fund company contravenes rule 120(1), the company commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: If a person contravenes rule 120(5), the person commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.
If a person is charged with an offence under subrule (2) for contravening rule 120(5), it is a defence to establish that the person took all reasonable steps to secure compliance with that rule.

section.name: s122
section.heading: Court may order statement of circumstances not to be sent

subsection.content: This rule applies if an application has been made under rule 120(1)(b) or (3) in relation to a statement of circumstances given by a person to an open-ended fund company under rule 119(1)(a).

subsection.leadIn: If the Court is satisfied that the person who gave the statement of circumstances has abused the use of the statement, or is using the statement to secure needless publicity for defamatory matter, the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must direct that copies of the statement are not to be sent under rule 120(1)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may order the person, though not a party to the application, to pay the applicant’s costs on the application in whole or in part.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court gives directions under subrule (2)(a), the open-ended fund company must, within 15 days beginning on the date on which the directions are given—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: send a notice setting out the effect of the directions to—

subparagraph.content: every shareholder of the company; and
unless already named as a party to the proceedings, the person who has given the statement of circumstances to the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: deliver to the Registrar for registration, a copy of the notice.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court decides not to grant the application, the open-ended fund company must, within 15 days beginning on the date on which the decision is made or on which the proceedings are discontinued for any reason—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give notice of the decision to the person who has given the statement of circumstances to the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send a copy of the statement of circumstances to every shareholder of the company and to that person.

subsection.content: Within 7 days beginning on the date on which a person receives a notice under subrule (4)(a), the person must deliver to the Registrar for registration, a copy of the statement of circumstances.

section.name: s123
section.heading: Offences relating to rule 122

subsection.leadIn: If an open-ended fund company contravenes rule 122(3) or (4), the company commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes rule 122(5) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.
If a person is charged with an offence under subrule (2) for contravening rule 122(5), it is a defence to establish that the person took all reasonable steps to secure compliance with that rule.

section.name: s124
section.heading: Qualified privileges

subsection.content: In the absence of malice, a person is not liable to any action for defamation at the suit of any person in respect of the making of a statement of circumstances and giving the statement to an open-ended fund company under rule 119.
This rule does not limit or affect any other right, privilege or immunity that a custodian of an open-ended fund company, or any other person, has as defendant in an action for defamation.

section.name: s125
section.heading: Appointment of investment manager

subsection.content: With effect from the date of incorporation of an open-ended fund company, the person named in the application made under section 112D or 112ZJB of the Ordinance in respect of the company as investment manager is deemed to be appointed as the company’s investment manager for the purposes of section 112Z(1) of the Ordinance. (33 of 2021 s. 23)
Any subsequent appointment of an investment manager of an open-ended fund company must be made by the directors of the company.
An appointment under subrule (2) must not be made unless the Commission has given its approval to the appointment.
An appointment in contravention of subrule (3) is of no effect.

section.name: s126
section.heading: Rights of investment manager
section.leadIn: An investment manager of an open-ended fund company is entitled—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be given all notices of, and other communications relating to, any general meeting of the company as a shareholder of the company is entitled to be given;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to attend any general meeting of the company; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to be heard at any general meeting of the company that the investment manager attends on any part of the business of the meeting that concerns the investment manager as investment manager of the company.

section.name: s127
section.heading: Resignation etc. of investment manager

subsection.content: If a person ceases to be an investment manager of an open-ended fund company, other than by virtue of an order of the Court made under section 213 or 214A of the Ordinance, the company must, within 15 days after the cessation, give notice in writing of the cessation to the Commission.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s128
section.heading: Eligibility for appointment

subsection.content: Only a practice unit is eligible for appointment as auditor of an open-ended fund company.

subsection.leadIn: The following are disqualified for appointment as auditor of an open-ended fund company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who is an officer or employee of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who is a partner or employee of a person mentioned in paragraph (a).

subsection.leadIn: In subrule (1)—
subsection.def: practice unit (執業單位) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Accounting and Financial Reporting Council Ordinance (Cap. 588). (L.N. 66 of 2022)

subsection.content: In subrule (2)(a), a reference to an officer or employee of an open-ended fund company does not include an auditor of the company.

section.name: s129
section.heading: Effect of appointing firm as auditor
section.leadIn: If a firm is appointed, by the firm name, as auditor of an open-ended fund company, the appointment is to be regarded as an appointment of those persons who are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the partners in the firm from time to time during the currency of the appointment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: eligible, and not disqualified, for appointment as auditor of the company under this Subdivision.

section.name: s130
section.heading: Appointment of auditor by directors
section.content: Subject to any provision of the instrument of incorporation of an open-ended fund company for the appointment of an auditor of the company, the directors of an open-ended fund company may appoint an auditor for the company.

section.name: s131
section.heading: Appointment to fill casual vacancy

subsection.content: The directors of an open-ended fund company may appoint a person to fill a casual vacancy in the office of auditor of the company.

If the directors have not done so within 1 month after the casual vacancy occurs, the shareholders of the company may, by a resolution passed at a general meeting of the company, appoint a person to fill the casual vacancy.

section.name: s132
section.heading: Auditor’s remuneration

subsection.content: The remuneration of an auditor of an open-ended fund company appointed by the directors of the company must be fixed by the directors when making the appointment.

subsection.leadIn: The remuneration of an auditor of an open-ended fund company appointed by the shareholders of the company may be fixed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a resolution passed at a general meeting of the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the manner as specified in such a resolution.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: remuneration (酬金), in relation to an auditor of an open-ended fund company, includes any sum paid by the company in respect of the expenses of the auditor.

section.name: s133
section.heading: Rights of auditor in relation to general meeting

subsection.leadIn: A person appointed as auditor of an open-ended fund company is entitled—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to attend any general meeting of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to be heard at any general meeting of the company that the person attends on any part of the business of the meeting that concerns the person as auditor of the company.

subsection.content: A person’s entitlement under subrule (1)(a) or (b) is, if the person is a firm or body corporate, exercisable by a natural person authorized by the person to act as the person’s representative at the meeting.

section.name: s134
section.heading: Rights of auditor in relation to information

subsection.content: An auditor of an open-ended fund company has a right of access to the company’s accounting records.

An auditor of an open-ended fund company may require a person that is a related entity of the company, or was a related entity of the company at the time to which the information or explanation relates, to provide the auditor with any information or explanation that the auditor reasonably requires for the performance of the duties as auditor of the company.

If an auditor has required a person to provide any information or explanation under subrule (2), the person must provide the information or explanation as soon as reasonably practicable after being required.

A statement made by a person in response to a requirement under subrule (2) may not be used in evidence against the person in any criminal proceedings except proceedings for an offence under rule 135.
This rule does not compel a person to disclose information in respect of which a claim to legal professional privilege could be maintained in legal proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: related entity (有關連實體), in relation to an open-ended fund company, means—(a)an officer of the company;(b)a custodian of the company; or(c)a person holding or accountable for any of the accounting records of the company.

section.name: s135
section.heading: Offences relating to rule 134

subsection.content: A person who contravenes rule 134(3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.
If a person is charged with an offence under subrule (1), it is a defence to establish that it was not reasonably practicable for the person to provide the information or explanation.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person makes a statement to an auditor of an open-ended fund company that conveys or purports to convey any information or explanation that the auditor requires, or is entitled to require, under rule 134(2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the statement is misleading, false or deceptive in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether or not, the statement is misleading, false or deceptive in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subrule (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: This rule does not affect an auditor’s right to apply for an injunction to enforce any of the auditor’s rights under rule 134.

section.name: s136
section.heading: Auditor may provide information to incoming auditor without contravening duties

subsection.leadIn: A person who is, or has been, an auditor of an open-ended fund company does not contravene any duty owed by the person as such auditor in law by reason only that the person gives work-related information to another person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is an auditor of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who has been appointed as auditor of the company but whose term of office has not yet begun; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to whom the company has offered the position as auditor but who has not yet been appointed.

subsection.leadIn: Subrule (1) does not apply unless the person who gives work-related information to another person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: does so in good faith; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: reasonably believes that the information is relevant to the performance of that other person’s duties as auditor of the open-ended fund company.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: work-related information (工作資料), in relation to a person who is, or has been, an auditor of an open-ended fund company, means information of which the person became aware in the capacity of auditor.

section.name: s137
