section.heading: Qualified privileges

subsection.content: In the absence of malice, an auditor of an open-ended fund company is not liable to any action for defamation at the suit of any person in respect of any statement made by the auditor in the course of performing duties as auditor of the company.

subsection.leadIn: In the absence of malice, a person is not liable to any action for defamation at the suit of any person in respect of the publication of any document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prepared by an auditor of an open-ended fund company in the course of performing duties as auditor of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: required by the Ordinance—

subparagraph.content: to be delivered to the Registrar; or
to be sent to a shareholder of the company or any other person.

subsection.content: This rule does not limit or affect any other right, privilege or immunity that an auditor of an open-ended fund company, or any other person, has as defendant in an action for defamation.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule, a reference to performing duties as auditor of an open-ended fund company includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: making a cessation statement, giving the statement to the company, and requesting the company to comply with the requirement specified in rule 143(4) in relation to the statement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: making a statement of circumstances and giving the statement to the company.

section.name: s138
section.heading: Resignation of auditor

subsection.content: A person may resign from the office of auditor of an open-ended fund company by giving the company a notice in writing that is accompanied by a statement required to be given under rule 144.

subsection.leadIn: The person’s term of office expires—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the end of the day on which the notice is given to the company under subrule (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the notice specifies a time on a later day for the purpose, at that time.

subsection.content: Within 15 days beginning on the date on which an open-ended fund company receives a notice of resignation under subrule (1), the company must deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice in specified form of that fact.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (3), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $1,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s139
section.heading: Cessation of office

subsection.leadIn: If, while holding office as auditor of an open-ended fund company, a person ceases to be eligible, or becomes disqualified, for appointment as auditor of the company under this Division, the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: immediately ceases to be an auditor of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must notify the company of the cessation in writing within 14 days from the date of the cessation.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subrule (1)(b) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

If a person is charged with an offence under subrule (2), it is a defence to establish that the person did not know, and had no reason to believe, that the person had ceased to be eligible, or had become disqualified, for appointment as auditor of the open-ended fund company under this Division.

section.name: s140
section.heading: Removal of auditor

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company may, by an ordinary resolution passed at a general meeting of the company, remove a person from the office of auditor despite—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: anything in any agreement between the person and the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: anything in the company’s instrument of incorporation.

subsection.content: Special notice is required for an ordinary resolution proposed for the purposes of subrule (1).
On receipt of a special notice, the open-ended fund company must send a copy of it to the person proposed to be removed.

If an ordinary resolution for the removal is passed, the company must, within 15 days beginning on the date on which it is passed, deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice of the removal in specified form.

If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (4), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3, and in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s141
section.heading: Removed auditor not deprived of compensation, etc.
section.leadIn: Rule 140 does not deprive a person of compensation or damages payable to the person in respect of the person ceasing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to hold office as auditor of an open-ended fund company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to hold any appointment that is terminated with the termination of the person’s appointment as auditor.

subdivision.name: SD4
subdivision.heading: Outgoing Auditor’s Right to Requisition General Meeting

section.name: s142
section.heading: Resigning auditor may requisition meeting

subsection.content: If a person gives under rule 138 a notice of resignation that is accompanied by a statement of circumstances given under rule 144(1)(a), the person may, by another notice given to the open-ended fund company with the notice of resignation, require the directors to convene a general meeting of the company for receiving and considering the explanation of the circumstances connected with the resignation that the person places before the meeting.

Within 21 days beginning on the date on which the company receives that other notice, the directors of the company must convene a general meeting for a date falling within 28 days after the date on which the notice convening the meeting is given.

subsection.leadIn: If the directors of an open-ended fund company contravene subrule (2), every director who failed to take all reasonable steps to secure that a general meeting of the company was convened as required by that subrule commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s143
section.heading: Cessation statement in relation to, and attendance at, general meeting

subsection.leadIn: If a general meeting of an open-ended fund company is convened under rule 142, the person who resigns from the office of auditor—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may give the company a statement by the person that sets out in reasonable length the circumstances surrounding the resignation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may request the company to comply with the requirement specified in subrule (4) in relation to the statement; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: is entitled—

subparagraph.content: to be given all such notices of, and other communications relating to, the general meeting of the company as a shareholder of the company is entitled to be given;
to attend the general meeting; and
to be heard, at the general meeting, on any part of the business of the meeting that concerns the person as auditor or former auditor of the company.

subsection.leadIn: If special notice is given under rule 140(2) for an ordinary resolution for removing a person from the office of auditor, the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may give the company a statement by the person that sets out in reasonable length the circumstances surrounding the proposed removal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may request the company to comply with the requirement specified in subrule (4) in relation to the statement.

subsection.content: A person’s entitlement under subrule (1)(c)(ii) or (iii) is, if the person is a firm or body corporate, exercisable by a natural person authorized by the person to act as the person’s representative at the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: The requirement specified for the purposes of subrules (1)(b) and (2)(b) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the open-ended fund company receives the statement on a date that is more than 2 days before the last day on which notice may be given under rule 78 to call the general meeting, the requirement—

subparagraph.content: to state, in every notice of the meeting given to the shareholders, that the statement has been made; and
to send a copy of the statement to every shareholder to whom a notice of the meeting is or has been given; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the open-ended fund company has not sent a copy of the statement to every shareholder to whom a notice of the general meeting is or has been given, the requirement to ensure that the statement is read out at the meeting.

subsection.content: Unless exempted by an order under subrule (6), the open-ended fund company must comply with a request made under subrule (1)(b) or (2)(b).

subsection.leadIn: On application by the company or by anyone who claims to be aggrieved, the Court may order that the open-ended fund company is exempted from complying with the request, if it is satisfied that the person who has given a statement and made a request under subrules (1)(a) and (b) or (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has abused the right to do so; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has used such a right to secure needless publicity for defamatory matter.

subsection.content: If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (5), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s144
section.heading: Duty of resigning auditor to give statement

subsection.leadIn: A person who resigns from office under rule 138(1) must, on the resignation, give the open-ended fund company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person considers that there are circumstances connected with the resignation that should be brought to the attention of the company’s shareholders or creditors, a statement of those circumstances; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person considers that there are no such circumstances, a statement to that effect.

subsection.content: The person referred to in subrule (1) must, at the time of giving the open-ended fund company a statement under subrule (1)(a) or (b), send a copy of the statement to the Commission.

section.name: s145
section.heading: Open-ended fund company’s and aggrieved person’s responses to statement of circumstances

subsection.leadIn: If an open-ended fund company is given a statement of circumstances under rule 144(1)(a), the company must, within 14 days beginning on the date on which it receives the statement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: send a copy of the statement to every shareholder of the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply to the Court for an order directing that copies of the statement are not to be sent under paragraph (a).

subsection.content: If an open-ended fund company makes an application under subrule (1)(b), it must give notice of the application to the person who has given the statement of circumstances to the company.

A person who claims to be aggrieved by a statement of circumstances may, within 14 days beginning on the date on which the open-ended fund company receives the statement, apply to the Court for an order directing that copies of the statement are not to be sent under subrule (1)(a).

subsection.leadIn: If a person makes an application under subrule (3), the person must give notice of the application to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the open-ended fund company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person who has given the statement of circumstances to the company.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person gives an open-ended fund company a statement of circumstances; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within 21 days beginning on the date on which the company receives the statement, the person has not received notice of an application under subrule (2) or (4),

subsection.continued: the person must, within the next 7 days, deliver to the Registrar for registration, a copy of the statement.

subsection.leadIn: If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (1), the company commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: If a person contravenes subrule (5), the person commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.
If a person is charged with an offence under subrule (7), it is a defence to establish that the person took all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subrule (5).

section.name: s146
section.heading: Court may order statement of circumstances not to be sent

subsection.content: This rule applies if an application has been made under rule 145(1)(b) or (3) in relation to a statement of circumstances given by a person to an open-ended fund company under rule 144(1)(a).

subsection.leadIn: If the Court is satisfied that the person has abused the use of the statement of circumstances or is using the statement to secure needless publicity for defamatory matter, the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must direct that copies of the statement are not to be sent under rule 145(1)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may order the person, though not a party to the application, to pay the applicant’s costs on the application in whole or in part.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court gives directions under subrule (2)(a), the open-ended fund company must, within 15 days beginning on the date on which the directions are given—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: send a notice setting out the effect of the directions to—

subparagraph.content: every shareholder of the company; and
unless already named as a party to the proceedings, the person who has given the statement of circumstances to the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: deliver to the Registrar for registration, a copy of the notice.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court decides not to grant the application, the open-ended fund company must, within 15 days beginning on the date on which the decision is made or on which the proceedings are discontinued for any reason—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give notice of the decision to the person who has given the statement of circumstances to the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send a copy of the statement of circumstances to every shareholder of the company and to that person.

subsection.content: Within 7 days beginning on the date on which a person receives a notice under subrule (4)(a), the person must deliver to the Registrar for registration, a copy of the statement of circumstances.

section.name: s147
section.heading: Offences relating to rule 146

subsection.leadIn: If an open-ended fund company contravenes rule 146(3) or (4), the company commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes rule 146(5) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.
If a person is charged with an offence under subrule (2) for contravening rule 146(5), it is a defence to establish that the person took all reasonable steps to secure compliance with that rule.

section.name: s148
section.heading: Financial year

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company’s first financial year begins on the first day of its first accounting reference period and ends on the last day of that period.

Every subsequent financial year of an open-ended fund company begins on the date immediately following the end of the previous financial year and ends on the last day of the accounting reference period immediately following the one by reference to which the previous financial year is determined.

section.name: s149
section.heading: Accounting reference period

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company’s first accounting reference period begins on the date of its incorporation and ends on its primary accounting reference date.

Every subsequent accounting reference period of an open-ended fund company is the period of 12 months beginning immediately after the end of the previous accounting reference period and ending on its accounting reference date, unless the accounting reference period is shortened or extended by the directors after consultation with the auditors of the company.
The directors must not extend the accounting reference period so as to extend the period to longer than 18 months.
Subject to subrule (5), an open-ended fund company’s accounting reference date is the anniversary of a company’s primary accounting reference date.

Subject to subrule (6), the directors of an open-ended fund company may specify a new accounting reference date in relation to the company’s accounting reference period and every subsequent accounting reference period.
The directors of an open-ended fund company must not specify a new accounting reference date in relation to an accounting reference period so as to extend the period to longer than 18 months.

section.name: s150
section.heading: Primary accounting reference date

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company’s primary accounting reference date is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a date specified by the company’s directors before the relevant date for the purposes of this rule; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the absence of such a specified date, the relevant date.

subsection.content: A date specified for the purposes of subrule (1)(a) must fall within 18 months after the date of the company’s incorporation.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: relevant date (有關日期) means the last day of the month in which the first anniversary of the open-ended fund company’s date of incorporation falls. (33 of 2021 s. 24)

section.name: s151
section.heading: Annual report

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company’s directors must prepare a report (annual report) for each financial year.
The company must publish the annual report and provide, on request, a copy of the report free of charge to any shareholder.

On application by the company, the Commission may, if it considers appropriate in the circumstances, exempt the directors from the requirement under subrule (1) and the company from the requirement under subrule (2).

section.name: s152
section.heading: Accounts in annual report

subsection.leadIn: An annual report of an open-ended fund company must, in respect of the financial year to which it relates, contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the financial statements of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the auditor’s report on the financial statements referred to in rule 153(1).

subsection.leadIn: The financial statements for a financial year must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give a true and fair view of the financial position and financial performance of the company as at the end of the financial year;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: comply with the accounting standards applicable to the financial statements;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if, in relation to any of the financial statements, compliance with paragraph (b) would be insufficient to give a true and fair view under paragraph (a)—contain all additional information necessary for that purpose; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if, in relation to any of the financial statements, compliance with paragraph (b) would be inconsistent with a requirement to give a true and fair view under paragraph (a)—

subparagraph.content: depart from paragraph (b) to the extent necessary for it to give a true and fair view; and
contain the reasons for, and the particulars and effect of, the departure.

subsection.content: The accounting standards applicable to the financial statements for the purposes of subrule (2) are the accounting standards specified for this purpose in the OFC code.

section.name: s153
section.heading: Auditor’s report

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company’s auditor must prepare a report for the shareholders of the company on any financial statements prepared by the directors and included in the annual report of the company during the auditor’s term of office.

subsection.leadIn: An auditor’s report under subrule (1) must state, in the auditor’s opinion—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the financial statements have been properly prepared in compliance with these Rules; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in particular, whether the financial statements give a true and fair view of the financial position and financial performance of the open-ended fund company.

section.name: s154
section.heading: Auditor’s opinion on other matters

subsection.leadIn: In preparing an auditor’s report under rule 153(1), the auditor must carry out an investigation that will enable the auditor to form an opinion as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether adequate accounting records have been kept by the open-ended fund company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the financial statements are in agreement with the accounting records.

subsection.leadIn: An open-ended fund company’s auditor must state the auditor’s opinion in the auditor’s report if the auditor is of the opinion that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: adequate accounting records have not been kept by the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the financial statements are not in agreement with the accounting records in any material respect.

subsection.content: If an open-ended fund company’s auditor fails to obtain all the information or explanations that, to the best of the auditor’s knowledge and belief, are necessary and material for the purpose of the audit, the auditor must state that fact in the auditor’s report.

section.name: s155
section.heading: Offences relating to contents of auditor’s report

subsection.content: Every person specified in subrule (2) commits an offence if the person knowingly or recklessly causes a statement required to be contained in an auditor’s report under rule 154(2)(b) or (3) to be omitted from the report.

subsection.leadIn: The persons are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the auditor who prepares the auditor’s report is a natural person—

subparagraph.content: the auditor; and
every employee and agent of the auditor who is eligible for appointment as auditor of the open-ended fund company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the auditor who prepares the auditor’s report is a firm—every partner, employee and agent of the auditor who is eligible for appointment as auditor of the open-ended fund company; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the auditor who prepares the auditor’s report is a body corporate—every officer, shareholder, employee and agent of the auditor who is eligible for appointment as auditor of the open-ended fund company.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subrule (1) is liable on conviction to a fine of $150,000.

section.name: s156
section.heading: Auditor’s reports to be signed

subsection.leadIn: An auditor’s report must be signed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the auditor is a natural person—by the auditor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the auditor is a firm or body corporate—by a natural person authorized to sign the auditor’s name on the auditor’s behalf.

subsection.content: An auditor’s report must state the auditor’s name.

An open-ended fund company must ensure that every copy of an auditor’s report laid before the company in general meeting, or otherwise circulated, published or issued by the company, states the auditor’s name.
If an open-ended fund company contravenes subrule (3), the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s157
section.heading: Open-ended fund company must keep accounting records

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must keep accounting records that comply with subrules (2) and (3).

subsection.leadIn: The accounting records must be sufficient—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to show and explain the company’s transactions;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to disclose with reasonable accuracy the company’s financial position and financial performance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to enable the directors to ensure that the financial statements comply with these Rules.

subsection.leadIn: In particular, the accounting records must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: daily entries of all sums of money received and expended by the open-ended fund company, and the matters in respect of which the receipt and expenditure takes place; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a record of the company’s assets and liabilities.

subsection.content: A director of an open-ended fund company who fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subrule (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $300,000.

A director of an open-ended fund company who wilfully fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subrule (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $300,000 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is charged with an offence under subrule (4), it is a defence to establish that the person had reasonable grounds to believe, and did believe, that a competent and reliable person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was charged with the duty of ensuring that subrule (1) was complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was in a position to discharge that duty.

section.name: s158
section.heading: Implied terms implied in contracts with open-ended fund company with sub-funds
section.leadIn: The following terms are implied in every contract, agreement, arrangement or transaction entered into by an open-ended fund company with sub-funds—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a party contracting with the company agrees not to seek, in any proceedings or by any other means, to have recourse to any assets of any sub-fund of the company in the discharge of all or any part of a liability that was not incurred on behalf of the sub-fund;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a party contracting with the company succeeds by any means in having recourse to any assets of any sub-fund of the company in the discharge of all or any part of a liability that was not incurred on behalf of the sub-fund, the party is liable to the company to pay a sum equal to the value of the benefit that the party obtained as a result;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if a party contracting with the company succeeds in seizing or attaching by any means, or otherwise levying execution against, any assets of a sub-fund of the company in respect of a liability that was not incurred on behalf of the sub-fund, the party will hold those assets or the direct or indirect proceeds of the sale of those assets on trust for the company and will keep those assets or proceeds separate and identifiable as trust property.

section.name: s159
section.heading: Cross sub-fund investment
section.content: Despite any rule of law that prohibits or restricts a corporation from acquiring its own shares, an open-ended fund company with sub-funds may, for the account of any of its sub-funds, acquire by subscription or transfer for consideration shares of any class or classes, however described, representing other sub-funds of the same open-ended fund company.

section.name: s160
section.heading: New sub-funds and termination of sub-funds

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company must not establish a sub-fund of the company unless the Commission has given its approval for the company to establish the sub-fund.
Subrule (1) does not apply to a sub-fund of an open-ended fund company established on the date of incorporation of the company.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: Subrule (1) also does not apply to a sub-fund of a re-domiciled OFC in existence on the re-domiciliation date of the re-domiciled OFC. (33 of 2021 s. 25)
An open-ended fund company must not terminate a sub-fund of the company unless the Commission has given its approval for the company to terminate the sub-fund.

section.name: s161
section.heading: Change of name of sub-fund
section.content: An open-ended fund company must not change the name of a sub-fund of the company unless the Commission has given its approval for the company to change the name of the sub-fund.

section.name: s162
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: arrangement (安排) includes a reorganization of a company’s share capital by consolidation of shares of different classes, or by division of shares into different classes, or both;
company (公司) means an open-ended fund company.

section.name: s163
section.heading: Application
section.leadIn: This Part applies if an arrangement or compromise is proposed to be entered into by a company with either or both of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the creditors, or any class of the creditors, of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the shareholders, or any class of the shareholders, of the company.

section.name: s164
section.heading: Court may order meeting of creditors or shareholders to be summoned

subsection.content: The Court may, on application made for the purposes of this subrule, order a meeting specified in subrule (2)(a), or a meeting specified in subrule (2)(b), or both, to be summoned in any manner that the Court directs.

subsection.leadIn: The meeting is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the arrangement or compromise is proposed to be entered into—

subparagraph.content: with the creditors of the company, a meeting of those creditors; or
with a class of the creditors of the company, a meeting of that class of creditors; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the arrangement or compromise is proposed to be entered into—

subparagraph.content: with the shareholders of the company, a meeting of those shareholders; or
with a class of the shareholders of the company, a meeting of that class of shareholders.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subrule (4), an application for the purposes of subrule (1) may be made only by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a meeting of creditors—the company or any of the creditors;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a meeting of a class of creditors—the company or any creditor of that class;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a meeting of shareholders—the company or any of the shareholders; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of a meeting of a class of shareholders—the company or any shareholder of that class.

subsection.content: If the company is being wound up, an application for the purposes of subrule (1) may be made only by the liquidator.
An application for the purposes of subrule (1) must be made in a summary way.

section.name: s165
section.heading: Explanatory statements to be issued or made available to creditors or shareholders

subsection.leadIn: If a meeting is summoned under rule 164—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every notice summoning the meeting that is sent to a creditor or shareholder must be accompanied by an explanatory statement complying with subrules (3) and (4); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: every notice summoning the meeting that is given by advertisement—

subparagraph.content: must include an explanatory statement complying with subrules (3) and (4); or
must state where and how a creditor or shareholder entitled to attend the meeting may obtain a copy of the explanatory statement.

subsection.content: If a notice given by advertisement states that a creditor or shareholder entitled to attend the meeting may obtain a copy of an explanatory statement, the company must provide a copy of the statement, free of charge, to a creditor or shareholder applying in the manner specified in the notice.

subsection.leadIn: An explanatory statement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must explain the effect of the arrangement or compromise; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must state—

subparagraph.content: any material interests of the company’s directors, whether as directors or as shareholders or as creditors of the company or otherwise, under the arrangement or compromise; and
the effect of the arrangement or compromise on those interests, in so far as the effect is different from the effect on the like interests of other persons.

subsection.content: If the arrangement or compromise affects the rights of the company’s debenture holders, an explanatory statement must give the like explanation as respects the trustees of any deed for securing the issue of the debentures as it is required to give as respects the directors.

subsection.leadIn: If subrule (1) or (2) is contravened, all of the following persons commit an offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every officer of the company who authorizes or permits, participates in, or fails to take all reasonable steps to prevent, the contravention;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a liquidator of the company who authorizes or permits, participates in, or fails to take all reasonable steps to prevent, the contravention;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a trustee of a deed for securing the issue of the company’s debentures who authorizes or permits, participates in, or fails to take all reasonable steps to prevent, the contravention.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subrule (5) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

If a person is charged with an offence under subrule (5) for a contravention of subrule (1), it is a defence to establish that the contravention was due to the refusal of another person, who was a director of the company or a trustee for debenture holders of the company, to supply the necessary particulars of that other person’s interests.

section.name: s166
section.heading: Directors and trustees must notify company of interest under arrangement or compromise etc.

subsection.content: If a meeting is summoned under rule 164, a director of the company, or a trustee for debenture holders of the company, must give notice to the company of any matters relating to the director or trustee that may be necessary for the purposes of rule 165.
A person who contravenes subrule (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s167
section.heading: Court may sanction arrangement or compromise

subsection.content: This rule applies if the creditors or the class of creditors, or the shareholders or the class of shareholders, or both, with whom the arrangement or compromise is proposed to be entered into, agree or agrees to the arrangement or compromise.
The Court may, on application made for the purposes of this subrule, sanction the arrangement or compromise.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subrule (4), an application for the purposes of subrule (2) may be made only by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an arrangement or compromise proposed to be entered into with the creditors of a company—the company or any of the creditors;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an arrangement or compromise proposed to be entered into with a class of creditors of a company—the company or any creditor of that class;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of an arrangement or compromise proposed to be entered into with the shareholders of a company—the company or any of the shareholders; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of an arrangement or compromise proposed to be entered into with a class of shareholders of a company—the company or any shareholder of that class.

subsection.content: If the company is being wound up, an application for the purposes of subrule (2) may be made only by the liquidator.

subsection.leadIn: An arrangement or compromise sanctioned by the Court under subrule (2) is binding—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the company or, if the company is being wound up, on the liquidator and contributories of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the creditors or the class of creditors, or the shareholders or the class of shareholders, or both, with whom the arrangement or compromise is proposed to be entered into.

subsection.content: An order made by the Court under subrule (2) has no effect until an office copy of the order is registered by the Registrar under Part 3.

If the order of the Court amends the company’s instrument of incorporation, or any resolution to which rule 97 applies, the office copy of that order delivered to the Registrar for registration for the purposes of subrule (6) must be accompanied by a copy of the instrument of incorporation, or the resolution, as amended.
If subrule (7) is contravened, the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s168
section.heading: Provision supplementary to rule 167(1): agreement to arrangement or compromise
section.leadIn: For the purposes of rule 167(1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the creditors agree to the arrangement or compromise if, at a meeting of the creditors summoned under rule 164, a majority in number representing at least 75% in value of the creditors present and voting, in person or by proxy, agree to the arrangement or compromise;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a class of creditors agrees to the arrangement or compromise if, at a meeting of the class of creditors summoned under rule 164, a majority in number representing at least 75% in value of the class of creditors present and voting, in person or by proxy, agree to the arrangement or compromise;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the shareholders agree to the arrangement or compromise if, at a meeting of the shareholders summoned under rule 164—

subparagraph.content: shareholders representing at least 75% of the voting rights of the shareholders present and voting, in person or by proxy, agree to the arrangement or compromise; and
unless the Court orders otherwise, a majority in number of the shareholders present and voting, in person or by proxy, agree to the arrangement or compromise; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: a class of shareholders agrees to the arrangement or compromise if, at a meeting of the class of shareholders summoned under rule 164—

subparagraph.content: shareholders representing at least 75% of the voting rights of the class of shareholders present and voting, in person or by proxy, agree to the arrangement or compromise; and
unless the Court orders otherwise, a majority in number of the class of shareholders present and voting, in person or by proxy, agree to the arrangement or compromise.

section.name: s169
section.heading: Court’s additional powers to facilitate reconstruction or amalgamation

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application is made for the purposes of rule 167(2) to sanction the arrangement or compromise; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: it is shown to the Court that—

subparagraph.content: the arrangement or compromise is proposed for the purpose of, or in connection with, a scheme for the reconstruction of one or more companies, or for the amalgamation of 2 or more companies; and
under the scheme, the property or undertaking of any company concerned in the scheme, or any part of that property or undertaking, is to be transferred to another company.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court sanctions the arrangement or compromise, it may, by the order or a subsequent order, make provision for any or all of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the transfer of the transferor’s property, undertaking or liabilities, or any part of it or them, to the transferee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the allotting or appropriation by the transferee of any shares, debentures, policies, or other like interests in the transferee which, under the arrangement or compromise, are to be allotted or appropriated by the transferee to or for any person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the continuation by or against the transferee of any legal proceedings pending by or against the transferor;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the dissolution, without winding up, of the transferor;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the provision to be made for any person, who within the time, and in the manner, that the Court directs, dissents from the arrangement or compromise;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the transfer or allotting of any interest in property to any person concerned in the arrangement or compromise;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any incidental, consequential and supplemental matters that are necessary to ensure that the reconstruction or amalgamation is fully and effectively carried out.

subsection.leadIn: If an order provides for the transfer of property under subrule (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the property is, by virtue of the order, transferred to, and vests in, the transferee; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the order so directs, the property vests freed from any charge that is to cease to have effect by virtue of the arrangement or compromise.

subsection.content: If an order provides for the transfer of liabilities under subrule (2), the liabilities are, by virtue of the order, transferred to, and become liabilities of, the transferee.

If the Court, by an order, makes provision for any matter under subrule (2), the order has no effect to the extent to which it purports to make the provision until an office copy of the order is registered by the Registrar under Part 3.

If the order of the Court amends the company’s instrument of incorporation, or any resolution to which rule 97 applies, the office copy of that order delivered to the Registrar for registration for the purposes of subrule (5) must be accompanied by a copy of the instrument of incorporation, or the resolution, as amended.
If subrule (6) is contravened, the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: liabilities (法律責任) includes—(a)duties of a personal character and incapable of being assigned or performed vicariously under the law; and(b)duties of any other description;
property (財產) includes—(a)rights and powers of a personal character and incapable of being assigned or performed vicariously under the law; and(b)rights and powers of any other description;

transferee (受讓人), in relation to an arrangement or compromise proposed for the purpose of a scheme of reconstruction or amalgamation, means the company to which another company’s property, undertaking or liabilities, or any part of it or them, is to be transferred under the scheme;

transferor (出讓人), in relation to an arrangement or compromise proposed for the purpose of a scheme of reconstruction or amalgamation, means the company whose property, undertaking or liabilities, or any part of it or them, is to be transferred to another company under the scheme.

section.name: s170
section.heading: Instrument of incorporation to be accompanied by order of Court

subsection.content: Every copy of the company’s instrument of incorporation issued by the company after an order is made for the purposes of rule 167 or 169 must be accompanied by a copy of the order, unless the effect of the order, and the effect of the arrangement or compromise to which the order relates, has been incorporated into the instrument of incorporation by alteration to that instrument of incorporation.
If subrule (1) is contravened, the company commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

division.name: D1
division.heading: Requirements for Appointment of Receivers and Managers, etc.

section.name: s171
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: Cap. 32 (第32章) means the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32);

relevant provisions of Cap. 32 (第32章的有關條文) means—(a)section 2 of Cap. 32;(b)section 79(1), (1A), (2) and (3) of Cap. 32;(c)Part VI of Cap. 32 except sections 298, 298A(3), 300(3), 300A(8) and 300B(7);(d)Part XIII of Cap. 32 except sections 349, 351A, 359A and 360; and(e)every item in the Twelfth Schedule to Cap. 32 providing for an offence under a relevant provision specified in paragraph (c);
subject provisions of Part 11 (第11部的標的條文) means the provisions referred to in rule 177(1).

section.name: s172
section.heading: Receivers and managers

subsection.content: The provisions (subject provisions) made for receivers and managers of the property of open-ended fund companies are the same as those relevant provisions of Cap. 32, subject to the necessary modifications and the modifications specified in rule 173.

subsection.leadIn: Accordingly—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reference to any of the subject provisions in relation to the application of these Rules may be expressed in any document in the form of a reference to a relevant provision of Cap. 32; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reference must be read subject to subrule (1).

subsection.content: A reference to a relevant provision of Cap. 32 (however described) in rule 173 in respect of which modification is required under that rule is a reference to a provision that is the same as the relevant provision.
A reference to a relevant provision of Cap. 32 (however described) in the subject provisions is a reference to a subject provision that is the same as the relevant provision.

section.name: s173
section.heading: Modifications

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of the subject provisions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reference to a company in a relevant provision of Cap. 32 is to be read as a reference to an open-ended fund company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reference to a member of a company in a relevant provision of Cap. 32 is to be read as a reference to a shareholder of an open-ended fund company; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a reference in a relevant provision of Cap. 32 to Cap. 32 (however described) is to be read as a reference to the subject provisions.

subsection.content: The references in section 79(1), (1A) and (2) of Cap. 32 to the provisions of Part V are to be read as a reference to the subject provisions of Part 11.
The references in section 79(1) and (1A) of Cap. 32 to section 265 are to be read as a reference to the subject provision of Part 11 that is the same as section 265 of Cap. 32.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Notice of Appointment and Cessation of Appointment

section.name: s174
section.heading: Notice of appointment of receiver or manager, etc.

subsection.content: If a person obtains an order for the appointment of a receiver or manager of the property of an open-ended fund company or appoints such a receiver or manager under the powers contained in an instrument, the person must, within 7 days after the date of the order or of the appointment under the powers (as the case requires), deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice including a statement of that fact.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subrule (1) must include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name and address of the person appointed as receiver or manager; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of the person’s identity card or, if the person does not have an identity card, the number and issuing country of any passport held by the person.

subsection.content: If a person enters into possession of the property of an open-ended fund company as mortgagee, the person must, within 7 days after the date of entering into possession, deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice including a statement of that fact.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subrule (3) must include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the person is a natural person—

subparagraph.content: the person’s name and address; and
the number of the person’s identity card or, if the person does not have an identity card, the number and issuing country of any passport held by the person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person is a body corporate—its name and the address of its registered or principal office.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subrule (1) or (3) must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the specified form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: accompanied by the applicable fee (if any).

subsection.content: If a person contravenes subrule (1) or (3), the person commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s175
section.heading: Notice of cessation of appointment, etc.

subsection.content: If a person appointed as receiver or manager under rule 174(1) ceases to act as receiver or manager, the person must, within 7 days after the date of the cessation, deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice including a statement of the cessation.

If a person mentioned in rule 174(3) goes out of possession of the property, the person must, within 7 days after going out of possession, deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice including a statement of that fact.

If there is any change to the particulars of the person included in a notice delivered to the Registrar under rule 174(1) or (3), the person must, within 15 days after the date of the change, deliver to the Registrar for registration, a notice including a statement of the change.

subsection.leadIn: Subrule (3) does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person mentioned in rule 174(1) who has ceased to act as receiver or manager and has delivered to the Registrar a notice under subrule (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person mentioned in rule 174(3) who has gone out of possession of the property and has delivered to the Registrar a notice under subrule (2).

subsection.content: A notice under subrule (1), (2) or (3) must be in the specified form.

If a person contravenes subrule (1), (2) or (3), the person commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.

part.name: P11
part.heading: Winding Up and Dissolution of Open-ended Fund Companies

division.name: D1
division.heading: Voluntary Winding Up of Open-ended Fund Companies

section.name: s176
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: Cap. 32 (第32章) means the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32);

relevant provisions of Cap. 32 (第32章的有關條文) means—(a)section 2 of Cap. 32;(b)Subdivision 2 of Division 1 of Part V of Cap. 32;(c)Division 3 of Part V of Cap. 32 except sections 228A(18) and (19) and 233(5), (6) and (7);(d)Divisions 4A and 6 of Part V of Cap. 32;(e)the provisions of Division 5 of Part V of Cap. 32 applicable to the voluntary winding up of a company, except sections 283(3), 286A and 296;(f)Part XIII of Cap. 32 except sections 349, 351A, 359A and 360;(g)every item in the Twelfth Schedule to Cap. 32 providing for an offence under a relevant provision of Cap. 32 referred to in paragraphs (c), (d) and (e);(h)Schedule 25 to Cap. 32; and(i)the provisions of the Companies (Winding-up) Rules (Cap. 32 sub. leg. H) (the Winding-up Rules) applicable to a voluntary winding up of a company except rule 117 of the Winding-up Rules.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of paragraphs (e) and (i) of the definition of relevant provisions of Cap. 32—
subsection.def: voluntary winding up (自動清盤) means a winding up commenced under Division 3 of Part V of Cap. 32.

section.name: s177
section.heading: Provisions for winding up

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company may be wound up under this Part (voluntary winding up) and the provisions (subject provisions) made for the voluntary winding up of open-ended fund companies and related or incidental matters are the same as those relevant provisions of Cap. 32, subject to the necessary modifications and the modifications specified in Division 2.

subsection.leadIn: Accordingly—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reference to any of the subject provisions in relation to the application of these Rules may be expressed in any document in the form of a reference to a relevant provision of Cap. 32; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reference must be read subject to subrule (1).

subsection.content: A reference to a relevant provision of Cap. 32 (however described) in Division 2 in respect of which modification is required under that Division is a reference to a provision that is the same as the relevant provision.
A reference to a relevant provision of Cap. 32 (however described) in the subject provisions is a reference to a subject provision that is the same as the relevant provision.

section.name: s178
section.heading: Modifications to general references

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of the subject provisions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reference to a company in a relevant provision of Cap. 32 is to be read as a reference to an open-ended fund company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reference to a member of a company in a relevant provision of Cap. 32 is to be read as a reference to a shareholder of an open-ended fund company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a reference to the articles of a company in a relevant provision of Cap. 32 is to be read as a reference to the instrument of incorporation of an open-ended fund company; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a reference to Cap. 32 or the Winding-up Rules (however described) in a relevant provision of Cap. 32 is to be read as a reference to the subject provisions.

subsection.content: A reference to general rules in sections 243(2) and 283(4) of Cap. 32 and in the item in the Twelfth Schedule to Cap. 32 for an offence under section 283(4) is to be read as a reference to the provisions of the Winding-up Rules referred to in paragraph (i) of the definition of relevant provisions of Cap. 32.

section.name: s179
section.heading: General meeting to fill vacancy in office of liquidators
section.content: The reference in section 236(3) of Cap. 32 to the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) is to be read as a reference to these Rules.

section.name: s180
section.heading: Power to apply to court to have questions determined or powers exercised
section.content: The reference in section 255(1) of Cap. 32 to liquidator or any contributory or creditor is to be read as a reference to liquidator, or the Commission or any contributory or creditor.

section.name: s181
section.heading: Saving for rights of creditors and contributories to apply for winding up of OFC as unregistered company

subsection.content: Section 257 of Cap. 32 is to be read as if “as an unregistered company” were inserted after “wound up by the court”.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def:
unregistered company (非註冊公司) has the meaning given by section 326 of Cap. 32. Note—
For the winding up by the court of an OFC as an unregistered company—see Part X of Cap. 32.

section.name: s182
section.heading: Persons disqualified from being appointed etc. as provisional liquidator or liquidator of open-ended fund company, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Section 262B(3) of Cap. 32 is to be read as if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the full stop were omitted and there were substituted a semicolon; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the following were added after paragraph (f)—

subparagraph.name: g
subparagraph.content: the investment manager of the company, or a person who has been an investment manager of the company;

subparagraph.name: h
subparagraph.content: the custodian of the company, or a person who has been a custodian of the company.”.

subsection.leadIn: Section 262D(2)(a) of Cap. 32 is to be read as if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: “or” were omitted in subparagraph (viii); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the following were added after subparagraph (ix)—

subparagraph.content: an investment manager of the company, its holding company or its subsidiary; or
a custodian of the company, its holding company or its subsidiary;”.

section.name: s183
section.heading: Liability where proper records not kept
section.content: The reference in section 274(1) of Cap. 32 to section 373(2) and (3) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) is to be read as a reference to rule 157.

section.name: s184
section.heading: Information as to pending liquidations
section.content: The reference in section 284(2) of Cap. 32 to prescribed fee is to be read as a reference to applicable fee.

section.name: s185
section.heading: Self-incrimination in relation to direction or requirement under certain subject provisions
section.content: The reference in section 286D(3)(a) of Cap. 32 to section 349 is to be read as a reference to rule 195.

section.name: s186
section.heading: Electronic communications by liquidators
section.leadIn: Section 296B(2)(d) of Cap. 32 is to be read as if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: “; or” were omitted in subparagraph (v);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the full stop were replaced by a semicolon in subparagraph (vi); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the following were added after subparagraph (vi)—

subparagraph.content: the Commission.”.

section.name: s187
section.heading: References, etc. in Companies (Winding-up) Rules
section.leadIn: In the Winding-up Rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the definition of relevant provision in rule 2(1) is to be read as if paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) were omitted and “the subject provisions” were substituted;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reference in rule 58(1)(d) to section 904(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) is to be read as a reference to section 112ZE of the Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the reference in rule 131 to section 606 or 607 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) is to be read as a reference to rule 85 or 86.

section.name: s188
section.heading: Winding up of sub-fund of open-ended fund company

subsection.content: Subject to subrules (2) and (3), a sub-fund of an open-ended fund company may be wound up under this Part as if it were a separate open-ended fund company.
A sub-fund of an open-ended fund company is to be treated as a separate legal person for the purposes of winding up of the sub-fund.

In relation to the winding up of a sub-fund of an open-ended fund company, the appointment of the liquidator and the powers and duties of the liquidator are confined to the sub-fund that is being wound up and its affairs, business and property.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subrule (1), a reference in the subject provisions relating to the winding up of an open-ended fund company to the following words is to be read as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: open-ended fund company is to be read as a reference to the sub-fund;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shareholder is to be read as a reference to a shareholder of the shares in the sub-fund; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: creditor is to be read as a reference to a creditor of the sub-fund.

subsection.content: An open-ended fund company with sub-funds may not sue or be sued in respect of a sub-fund of the company or exercise any rights of set-off in relation to the sub-fund after the appointment of a liquidator or provisional liquidator in respect of the winding up of the sub-fund.

section.name: s189
section.heading: Duty of liquidator of open-ended fund company to notify Commission

subsection.content: If the liquidator of an open-ended fund company is required under the subject provisions to summon a general meeting of the company, in the event of the winding up of the company continuing for more than one year, the liquidator must, within 7 days of summoning the meeting, notify the Commission in writing of the meeting.

If the liquidator of an open-ended fund company is required under the subject provisions to call a general meeting of the company for the purpose of laying before the company an account of the winding up of the company, the liquidator must, within 7 days of summoning the meeting, notify the Commission in writing of the meeting.

section.name: s190
section.heading: Official Receiver may disclose information to Commission
section.content: The Official Receiver may disclose to the Commission any information concerning an open-ended fund company or a sub-fund of an open-ended fund company obtained or received by the Official Receiver in the course of performing the Official Receiver’s functions under these Rules.

section.name: s191
section.heading: Registration of open-ended fund company cancelled on dissolution
section.content: The registration of an open-ended fund company is regarded as cancelled on dissolution of the company under the subject provisions or Part X of Cap. 32.

division.name: D5
division.heading: Dissolution of Open-ended Fund Company on Cancellation of Registration

section.name: s192
section.heading: Dissolution of open-ended fund company on cancellation of registration under section 112ZH of Ordinance

subsection.content: This rule applies if the Commission cancels the registration of an open-ended fund company under section 112ZH of the Ordinance.

The company is dissolved on the date of the cancellation of the registration of the company or such later date specified by the Commission in a notice of cancellation under section 112ZH of the Ordinance.

section.name: s193
section.heading: Dissolution of open-ended fund company on cancellation of registration under section 112ZI of Ordinance

subsection.content: This rule applies if the Commission cancels the registration of an open-ended fund company under section 112ZI of the Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The company is dissolved on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the cancellation has taken effect as a specified decision under section 232 of the Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such later date specified by the Commission in a notice of cancellation under section 112ZI of the Ordinance.

section.name: s194
section.heading: Application for cancellation of registration of open-ended fund company under section 112ZH of Ordinance
section.leadIn: An application by an open-ended fund company under section 112ZH of the Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be made in the manner specified by the Commission; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by any document or information that the Commission requires, and the applicable fee (if any).

section.name: s195
section.heading: Offence for false statement

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if, in any return, report, financial statements, certificate or any other document, required by or for the purposes of Part IVA of the Ordinance or these Rules, the person knowingly or recklessly makes a statement that is misleading, false or deceptive in a material particular.

Subrule (1) does not apply to the making of a statement that is misleading, false or deceptive in a material particular if the making of the statement would, apart from subrule (1), also constitute an offence under any of the relevant provisions.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subrule (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $300,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: This rule does not affect the operation of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Part V of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 19, 20 or 21 of the Theft Ordinance (Cap. 210).

section.name: s196
section.heading: Enforcement of requirements by order of Court

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if an open-ended fund company or an officer of an open-ended fund company contravenes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a requirement of these Rules—

subparagraph.content: to send, deliver, supply, forward or produce a document to the Registrar; or
to give notice to the Registrar of any matter; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a requirement of Part 10 or 11 of these Rules other than a requirement in paragraph (a).

subsection.content: The Registrar, or a shareholder or creditor of the company, may serve a notice on the company or officer requiring the company or officer to comply with the requirement.

subsection.leadIn: If the company or officer fails to make good the contravention within 14 days after service of the notice under subrule (2), the Court may, on application by the Registrar, or by a shareholder or creditor of the company, make an order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a contravention by the company—directing the company and any officer of the company to make good the contravention within the time specified in the order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a contravention by the officer—directing the officer to make good the contravention within the time specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: An order may provide that all costs of and incidental to the application are to be borne—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a contravention by the company—by the company, or by any officer of the company responsible for the contravention; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a contravention by the officer—by that officer.

subsection.content: This rule does not affect the operation of any Ordinance imposing penalties on an open-ended fund company or any officer of an open-ended fund company in respect of the contravention.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Particulars relating to proposed company
section.leadIn: The particulars specified for the purposes of rule 5(a) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name of the proposed company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the address of the proposed company’s registered office.

part.name: P2
part.heading: Particulars and Statement of Proposed Directors and Process Agents

section.name: s2
section.heading: Particulars of directors
section.leadIn: The particulars specified for the purposes of rule 5(b) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s present forename and surname, former forename or surname (if any), and aliases (if any);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person’s usual residential address; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number of the person’s identity card or, if the person does not have an identity card, the number and issuing country of any passport held by the person.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Statement relating to directors
section.leadIn: The statement specified for the purposes of rule 5(b) is a statement by the person that the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has consented to be a director of the open-ended fund company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has attained the age of 18 years.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Particulars of process agent of non-resident director
section.leadIn: The particulars specified for the purposes of rule 5(c) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name of the process agent;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the process agent is an individual—the process agent’s usual residential address in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the process agent is a company—the address of the company’s registered office in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the process agent is a partnership—the principal place of business of the partnership in Hong Kong.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Interpretation of this Part

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: forename (名字) includes a Christian or given name;
surname (姓氏), for a person usually known by a title different from the person’s surname, means that title.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, a reference to a former forename or surname does not include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to a person—

subparagraph.content: a forename or surname that was changed or ceased to be used before the person attained the age of 18 years; and
a forename or surname that has been changed or ceased to be used for at least 20 years;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a person usually known by a title different from the person’s surname, the name by which the person was known before the adoption of or succession to the title; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in relation to a married woman, a name or surname by which she was known before her marriage.

part.name: P3
part.heading: Statements Relating to Instrument of Incorporation

section.name: s6
section.heading: Statements relating to instrument of incorporation
section.leadIn: The statements specified for rule 5(d) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement that the proposed company’s instrument of incorporation has been signed by every person who is to be a director of the proposed company on the company’s incorporation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a statement that the contents of the copy of the proposed company’s instrument of incorporation, with or without the part showing the signature and the date of signing as they appear on the original document, are the same as those of the instrument of incorporation.

part.name: P1
part.heading: Particulars of Non-Hong Kong Fund Corporation and Intended OFC

section.heading: Particulars relating to non-Hong Kong fund corporation and intended OFC
section.leadIn: The particulars specified for the purposes of rule 8C(a) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the following particulars of the non-Hong Kong fund corporation—

subparagraph.content: its name;
its place of incorporation; and
whether it is registered as a registered non-Hong Kong company under Part 16 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622); and

paragraph.name: b

subparagraph.content: its proposed name; and
the address of its registered office.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Interpretation of this Part

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: forename (名字) includes a Christian or given name;
surname (姓氏), for a person usually known by a title different from the person’s surname, means that title.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, a reference to a former forename or surname does not include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to a person—

subparagraph.content: a forename or surname that was changed or ceased to be used before the person attained the age of 18 years; and
a forename or surname that has been changed or ceased to be used for at least 20 years;

paragraph.content: in relation to a person usually known by a title different from the person’s surname—the name by which the person was known before the adoption of or succession to the title; or

part.name: P3
part.heading: Statements relating to Instrument of Incorporation

section.name: s6
section.heading: Statements relating to instrument of incorporation
section.leadIn: The statements specified for rule 8C(d) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement that the intended OFC’s instrument of incorporation has been signed by every person who is to be a director of the intended OFC as from the re-domiciliation date of the intended OFC; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a statement that the contents of the copy of the intended OFC’s instrument of incorporation, with or without the part showing the signature and the date of signing as they appear on the original document, are the same as those of the instrument of incorporation.
